questions.q: What is often referred to as the 'Brain' of the computer?
questions.explanation: The Central Processing Unit (CPU) performs most of the processing inside a computer.
RAM is the short-term memory where data currently in use is stored.

questions.q: Which unit inside the CPU performs mathematical and logical operations?
questions.explanation: The ALU handles all arithmetic (addition, etc.) and logic (true/false) calculations.

questions.q: Which memory is the fastest but has the smallest capacity?
questions.explanation: Cache memory is built into the CPU to provide high-speed access to frequently used data.

questions.q: How many bits are in a single Byte?
questions.explanation: A byte is a unit of digital information that most commonly consists of eight bits.

questions.q: True or False: ROM (Read-Only Memory) is volatile, meaning it loses data when power is off.
questions.explanation: ROM is non-volatile; it keeps its data even without power.

questions.q: True or False: The motherboard is the main circuit board that connects all components.
questions.explanation: It serves as the 'spine' of the computer, allowing parts to communicate.

questions.q: True or False: A 64-bit processor can handle more data at once than a 32-bit processor.
questions.explanation: The bit-width refers to how much data the CPU can process in a single cycle.

questions.q: True or False: Registers are located inside the RAM.
questions.explanation: Registers are small, extremely fast storage locations located directly inside the CPU.

questions.q: True or False: An Output device allows the computer to send data to the user.
questions.explanation: Examples include monitors, printers, and speakers.

questions.q: Briefly explain the purpose of Computer Architecture.
questions.answer: Computer Architecture is the set of rules and methods that describe the functionality, organization, and implementation of computer systems.

questions.q: What is the difference between hardware and software?
questions.answer: Hardware refers to the physical components you can touch, while software refers to the digital instructions that tell the hardware what to do.
